comments.commentBody: Thank you for your beautiful writing - there's such a scarcity of it - and for a delicious essay on savoring and longing. So approachable and encouraging. Wishing you ease and unfettered joy on your travels.
Every day is a miracle, darling, trust me.
Wishing Amy and Jason love and peace in your final days.
I am the luckiest woman alive in that I had a husband like yours, Amy. My husband died three years ago after sharing  29 fabulous years with me.  I feel your anguish and share his pain.
A great architect said : "Less is more". Your story has brought that to,life for me. Love

As THEPLOTTHICKENS and INTHECROSSHAIRS appeared in that order I got giddy with how great those answers are. And my giddiness did not dissipate as I gamboled around the grid discovering more and more freshness and fun.

What a wonderful Saturday puzzle! It and you, Mary Lou Guizzo, sparkle!

.
A NYT feature recently presented 11 memorable Times crosswords.

All were Mondays or Tuesdays, so that newbies could attempt them. Brief intros told readers what was special about them.

I think the word used was "remarkable".

On one, a co-creator is Johanna _____ . WOW. I have a screen grab of that, with the headline. Not giving the link here because I don't know if you wish to be one-named on this Comments section. If you want the screen grab, Deb knows where to find me. So does Will and one of their test-solvers and a few of your fellow constructors. The trick to finding me on social media is not to look for "MTF Tobin" nor "Maura T. Fan".

An amethat (which is only two days old) is, indeed, some kind of cousin to a mondegreen.

It's an amusing misparsing of a multiple-word entry. RiA suggested the term in honor of suejean going astray when she had the beginnings of "(has) a name that" and thought the phrase would be "has an amethyst."

See, RiA. It didn't take long to catch on!

Many 403(b) accounts contact fixed accounts and some have guarantees with 3 or 4% minimums (especially older ones).  There are no fees deducted from these accounts and the interest rate stated is the interest rate given.  In this interest rate environment, it's a much better place to have safe money as opposed to the low interest rate/high risk of longer term bonds (IMHO).  It's where my wife has her money invested.  By your response, you aren't even aware of this benefit in some 403(b)s.  Perhaps better reporting is in order in the future.

I would never dare to assume that I (or readers) know all of the facts about all of the plans -- or even the facts of their own plans, given how complicated they are and all of the various ways that fees, surrender charges and other costs that have different names are attached to the accounts. Same way that I'd never assume that I could guess where the bond market is headed and make proportionate bets accordingly. I'm just trying to encourage the asking of inconvenient questions and radical humility about our ability to divine the answers and predict what the markets will do (while keeping in mind that a 3 or 4 percent guaranteed return may not be enough over time to provide a comfortable retirement, depending on your circumstances).

It's totally disgraceful that this the case.

Let me add to that the fact that teachers, who are so important to the next generation, to the success of our country, and to the health of the world, are one of the most despised and deprecated groups in our country today. That attitude of derision and distrust starts right with our current President and his Education Secretary.

Teachers should be given the same reverence we give doctors, and they should be well paid. How else can we attract the best people to teaching?

Note: I am not a teacher. I was, prior to retirement, a well-paid engineer. However, I often sought out interns for the businesses I worked for--and I know what a great teacher gives to his or her students: a lifetime of curiosity and enjoyment of learning.

Mr. Lieber,
Please indicate which comment you are replying to. Sometimes, it's difficult to properly interpret your comments out of context. Thank you.
Thanks for speaking up and apologies -- which comment was unclear? As best as I can tell, the replies show up under the comments that they are referring to, but I might have messed one up.

I am a recently retired teacher who contributed to a 403b with Voya. Thankfully I had not put a lot of money into this investment(?) only starting in 2013. But, after 3 years of excellent NYSE growth my Voya account had lost money. At no point over these last 3 years had my account balance ever exceeded my investment.I would have been better off putting my cash under the floorboards. I have been trying for 3 months to get my money out and have yet to see it. My advice, get in writing what all the fees are, and do not put your cash in their hands until you do.
Thanks for speaking up and apologies -- which comment was unclear? As best as I can tell, the replies show up under the comments that they are referring to, but I might have messed one up.

Uncle Donald passed his first test. He sounded presidential for an hour and used the old tried-and-true stage prop of a weeping widow to pull the wool over the eyes of the fake liberal establishment press.

Meanwhile, W jokes about "Mission Accomplished". Yea, funny stuff indeed. You can't fault W, who went AWOL defending Alabama from the Viet Cong, for failing to comprehend the fact that when you send soldiers off to war, some may get hurt or return in body bags.

And Donald, he of the bone spurs deferment, cannot be expected to understand that it was not necessary to sign-off on a risky mission to Yemen resulting in numerous dead and wounded children just to prove he is tougher than the drone king former president.

He should not have signed off on the Yemen plan. Then again, it should never have gotten to him, past responsible professional review.

What would have happened if Trump had vetoed it? There would have been a chorus of denunciation, that he refused the professional's plan left ready to go by Obama, because he sold out to Russia and its friends in Iran.

It wasn't ready, President Obama didn't have enough time left in office to finish the planning and review, which is why it was left for Trump to finalize.  What would have happened if Trump had not approved the plan?  A Navy Seal would be alive today.  As President it was Trump's decision and he decided badly.
So why do Americans keep electing these draft dodging sociopaths?

Thoroughly enjoyable Saturday puzzle that as usual seemed impossible but which turned out to be possible. Terrific long answers ANYONE LISTENING? (though that's more the exclamation of a frustrated speaker than someone testing one), THE PLOT THICKENS, IN THE CROSSHAIRS, and my favorite: TRIPLE WORD SCORE for the innocuous "Red square." Did not know Ms. SCHILLING, who Marion Cotillard played, the dragsters' group, the T.S. Eliot title, the palindromist, or the soccer guy. (Or why curlers are in RINKS, but will soon find out.) Like the name SPORCLE and seeing Phil OCHS and SHIRLEY CHISOLM. Cute that the two laugh sounds TEHEE and HAR are maximally far apart on the laugh spectrum. Nice to see the verb LEACH and the odd adjective SCUT. Thought the trans-Pacific clue for SFO was inspired. Nice to learn the M.L.K. quote.

Have often seen FIG. used as abbreviation for FIGURE when it means a number, and when it means an illustration. Not sure if I've ever seen FIG. used when it has another meaning, like a person, as in "Figs. seen in many police procedurals" for SGTS. But did not find this an easy question to settle by googling.
Think of "Is this thing on?" as a comic might say it when his jokes are dying.
Curling - a sport in the Winter Olympics
Aha — thanks, Dan and Rampiak!
Evan, Utah needs you as its next Senator or Congressman. I hope you'll consider it now.
The sea wall at Fukishima held, but the tsunami, quite simply, was higher than the barrier.  That's always a risk.

The East River and the harbor are no different now than they were 100 years ago, or even 500 years ago. I think manmade climate change is happening, and I don't doubt that. But predictions of what "might happen" with sea levels are just that: predictions with no proof, and hence there is nothing to get excited about at present, or even in the near future.

I did exactly that, and I am glad you're mentioning that too. The system is quite impressive.

I don't understand why some people think any company would spend $1MM without knowing what they're buying, especially if they're trying to protect property. Always so easy to think other people are fools...
THLOT PICKENS? SLIM chance.

Needed to say this sooner or later. We can't "stop" climate change. Maybe we can slow it down. Then the issue becomes how much do we spend now to prevent how much damage in the future. Another way: if we're going to fbe inundated three times a century instead of once, how much extra should we spend to mitigate thos effects? Put it another way: people choose to live on barrier islandas and histoic flood plains. Does that mean we should all make expensive changes in the way we live and do business to reduce their chance of flooding by a few percentage points?
Can somone paint me to someone who is being rational about his?

So SCUT is a proper name! I always fall asleep during that movie (too much rum in the eggnog?). Do we now need a special term for a Natick that isn't clued as such? Scuttled is all I can think of right now, have a puppy play date in, hmmm... about zero minutes. To Barry: PECS saved me also.

Either Saturdays just got easier, or I just got a lot better, or ML and I were just really on the same wavelength today. My money's on the last option.

Six grid-spanners, five of which I filled in super-quick! SHIRLEY CHISOLM was a (welcome) gimme. (I didn't live in her district, but I did send her campaign some money.) Got IN THE CROSSHAIRS from IN T; TRIPLE WORD SCORE from T?IP; THE PLOT THICKENS from TH?P?O; and ANYONE LISTENING after checking the downs to decide between that and ARE YOU LISTENING.

That left TAYLOR SCHILLING. I've never seen "Orange Is ..." since I don't have any premium channels. I got the TAYLOR part pretty quickly, since there seem to be an awful lot of them around right now. (Is "Taylor" the new "Morgan"?) The rest took a little longer, until finally I had a completed grid except for the intersection of SCHILLING and PHI. Had to be an E or an I, right? Good guess. I'm still not up on my rock bands, but I'm hoping somebody (Jimbo?) will explain PHI to me.

But that's okay. The puzzle put PIAF in my mind, and this evening's listening pleasure was decided upon.

I was also reminded of SPORCLE. A friend recommended it some years back, and I enjoyed it, and then somehow it fell out of my brain. I'll revisit.

That GD ending at 13D caused me to doubt briefly to doubt the arrangement of the stones in my cairn.

A very satisfying puzzler, with lots of sparkly fill. And loved the grid-spanners. Thanks to all.
It's a Macy's now, but the "Iggle" is still there. :)

Dang!

I was so proud of me for recognizing the name of a rock band! And then to find out I was wrong is just devastating. Once more, done in by a sports team. And further humiliation, I had to Google to find out which sport the Eagles play.

Grump.
Way to go! (And "Orange" is on Netflix, not any premium channel.)

I'm 47. I always tell kids in their teens and 20's to have as much sex as they can and to do as much skiing and surfing as possible. What sucks most about getting older is losing your body and losing your raw attractiveness to the opposite sex.

agreed - I observe in childcare -

those who share and play well with others are always walking around with a smile on their face with a group of friends having fun, helping others and enjoying being helped in return

those who are selfish and haven't learned to share (mostly from single child families) and get in 'gimme!' fights over stupid toys tend to walk around unhappy and disconcerted wondering why no-one wants to play with them

at a glance, their life prospects look very different

I love this piece.  Here's my advice:  when you're starting out in life in your 20s or 30s, take a look around you.  Who are the important people in your life?  Why?  Are they older?  Are they retired?  Who do you respect and marvel at?  Who makes you laugh?  Who loves life and stays positive day after day, even on the dark days.  And how do they do that.  After giving this some considerable thought, create an amalgam and make that your vision.  My grandmother lived every day like it was her last.  She had an unmatched joie de vivre.  She is an important component of my vision.  One day someone told me that they envy me because I have such joie de vivre.  I thanked them, but then I quietly thanked my grandmother who passed away a few years before when she was 100.  If someone tells me I possess those qualities, then I consider myself fortunate, not successful because that implies a destination.  It's a journey.  "We are here to laugh at the odds and live our lives so well, Death will tremble to take us."  Chas Bukowski
